request_pathways.name: Authorization to Use or Disclose Protected Health Information

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Patients must use a general-purpose HIPAA authorization form that covers both third-party release and patient self-access, selecting 'At my request' as the purpose.

red_flags: Form provides no submission instructions — no mailing address, fax number, or email — and Staff Use Only section implies in-person completion is expected
Form conflates patient self-access with third-party authorization, failing to inform patients of their distinct Right of Access protections
bright_spots: Granular record type options with itemized summary-of-care components
Well-structured minor consent section aligned with Washington State mature minor doctrine
Form easily discoverable online with no access barriers

findability.rationale: Level 4: Easy to find with a basic web search on the first attempt; no bot blocking or login walls, though the URL uses the 'ROI' acronym unfamiliar to patients.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 2: Primarily a paper workflow — the PDF has zero fillable fields, requiring print and handwrite, and the form implies in-person delivery with no electronic submission pathway indicated.

content_design.rationale: Level 3: Adequate single-page layout with logical flow but has notable problems — confusing 'initial one section' instruction, imprecise Title 42 reference, and dense formatting with minimal whitespace.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 3: A patient can use the process via the 'At my request' purpose option, but the form was not designed for patient self-access and does not reference Right of Access protections, fee limits, or response timelines.

compliance.rationale: Level 3: Some requirements that may go beyond what the law requires — apparent in-person submission expectation, no fee transparency, no response timeline, and conflation of patient access with third-party authorization obscures applicable legal protections.

overall.summary: Sea Mar provides an easily discoverable but paper-centric, undifferentiated authorization form that does not distinguish patient self-access from third-party release and appears to require in-person submission.
